narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I gained knowledge of automata theory and formal languages, how to use machines and understand languages, and logical thinking in general

Theoretical CS knowledge: DFA, NFA, regular expressions and regular languages, pumping lemmas, Turing machines, etc.
Mathematical proof for these topics.
Automata theory: DFA, NFA, regex, context-free grammar/language, pushdown automata, context-sensitive grammar, and turing machines, recognizability, decidability, etc.
Learned to understand computing from a mathematical perspective
I learned skills in theorem proving, automate theory, formal mathematics, and critical thinking.
A better understanding of various types of formal languages and the machine models used to model them. How to prove properties of languages and machines.
I learned about automata theory and the basics of formal languages and the theory behind computation
Introduction to Theoretical Computer Science
I developed knowledged of CS computation theory, starting from DFAs and working up to Turing Machines.

Learned about a bunch of different types of languages, ways to describe langauges and machines to recognize langauges. Was very abstract and low application potential. But that doesnt mean its not worth taking.
introduction to automata from a mostly proof-based perspective, practice writing proofs
Computability theory, theory of languages, Turing machines. A lot of proofs in this class.
I learned about the theory which underlies a lot of CS we do. DFAs, NFAs, PDAs, Turing Machines, etc. and their corresponding languages: regular languages, context-free languages, etc.
Automata theory

Definitions of various types of automata (non/deterministic finite automata, pushdown automata, Turing machines) as well as their corresponding language models (regular languages/expressions, context-free grammars), and various theories about those languages. Theories about language properties, computability, and decision problems. Focused on practicals like converting NFAs to DFAs, parsing words given a grammar, and implementing Turing machines.
Automata theory, Writing Proof
to improve computer theory knowledge
Mathematical proofs and reasoning; automata theory

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very strong course, great teacher
Professor Bridy teaches this course incredibly well - definitely the best CS course I've taken here. Problem sets were appropriately challenging.
clear and interesting topics, theoretical and mathematical, but no code as a CS course

The materials are interesting although I'm not sure they are all that useful except in some fields of CS (e.g. compilers). The first 90% of the lectures are very well organized and well delivered. There is clear logical flow from topic to topic and the ideas presented are very enlightening. However, towards the end, the lectures on turing machines become very confusing because the professor wasn't very good at explaining the reduction proofs. Overall though the class is very good and not heavy workload-wise.
Strengths is the material is clear and the professor is very good, could be improved by more practiced examples
This course was excellently done, and I would not change a single thing.

The material is surprisingly interesting and Professor Bridy does a great job of explaining concepts and making them accessible. The problem sets are straightforward and really help you understand the material better. I found the Turing machine/decidability unit to be a little repetitive and I think it could maybe be shortened, but that's the only suggestion I have.

Great course organization and very clear explanation of content during lecture. I only used my lecture notes to prepare for exams and didn't need to reference outside material. Overall I felt that I learned a lot from this class without it being very stressful, which feels rare for a CS class.
The material is pretty interesting and the course is well-paced.
Prof is the best explainer of all time. Every time he explained something I understood it immediately.
could probably include more discussion of why we study automata and how it relates to foundations of computer science, beyond just saying turing machines = computers

Professor Bridy was very deliberate in the way he explained many of the difficult concepts in the class. He limited the scope of the material where needed and although the homeworks were mostly proofs, they were of reasonable difficulty.

Strengths: teaching. He explains everything clearly and gives examples to make abstract ideas more tangible. 

Weaknesses: Being able to drop two entire homeworks is probably too lenient of a policy when only 8 were due for a grade.
It's interesting content not really covered in other CS courses at Yale. Bridy is really good at explaining things. I can't think of any obvious way to improve it.
Very interesting proofs and class engagement. Professor Bridy stresses the use of examples which is very helpful for understanding the topic.

Good background on the common machine models for computation. Rather practically focused which, in my opinion, is not as helpful given the unlikelihood of ever needing to perform procedures by hand. Homework was quite easy and not very proof-based which did not provide opportunities for intellectual challenge.
I think it's very organized.
It is a great theoretical course. It was fun playing with the various concepts related to automata, although I doubt those concepts themselves are useful for me outside of this course.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, if you are a CS student or understand logical mathematics, and formal mathematics. Definitely should be after discrete mathematics or CPSC 202
Definitely recommend
Yes
Yes, I like the topics and knowledge taught in this course. I like theoretical CS and mathematical proof. The assignment is useful and challenging.
Yes. The professor is a reasonably good lecturer and psets/exams are very fair. Give it a go if you wanna try out a more math/proof-heavy CS elective instead of those other coding classes.
I absolutely would. Although it was difficult as I did not have the entire mathematical background, I was able to catch up with the help of Professor Bridy and the TF.

Yes! If you're at all interested in formal computer science, it's a great CS elective that isn't too intense. Even if not, Professor Bridy does a great job of explaining the material and making it accessible. The weekly problem sets are straightforward, and while there are proofs, they are nowhere near as rigorous as a formal proof class.
I would definitely recommend this! If you want a interesting CS elective and like proofs, take this class

Yes! Great elective that would be a requirement at many other schools. However, the course content probably isn't super applicable if you'll go straight into software engineering. Towards the end the class became somewhat proof-heavy, though nothing too bad.
Yes if interested in theory.
yeah it is nice to take a break from coding and take a trip to abstract land.

yes, this is a pretty easy and interesting enough computer science elective. It's definitely helpful to have a good proof-writing background, but you actually don't need much if any math at all and honestly don't need that much of a coding background either. It was very chill -- open note take home exams, weekly psets that didn't take too long and were sometimes cancelled. Prof. Bridy is pretty accommodating.

Yes, this is a great CS elective to take. The options are limited when it comes to CS electives that are both well-taught and a reasonable amount of work.  Especially if you enjoy the more theoretical side of computer science, this is a great course.
A great chill elective if you want to further develop your understanding of the theory of computation. Perhaps it could have moved more quickly and had harder problems.

Yes, it's content that isn't really covered in detail by any other CS classes at Yale. Bridy is really nice and a great explainer. I took Compilers before taking this class, and it's nice to now understand more of the theory that we used in Compilers. Having taken algos, it would also be a nice warm-up to CS proofs. You really don't need any prereqs for it as long as you have written proofs before. Great class overall, and not a ton of work.
Yes, Professor Bridy is very knowledgeable of the field and explains things very well.
Only recommend this class for people who like to do proofs. Otherwise its going to be very hard and dense
Yes.
Absolutely, mostly because of Bridy. I don't think the subject comes up very frequently outside of the academic sphere directly related to it.
Yes if you want to learn some theory knowledge.

yes
the instructor made clear points on everything

Yes. It is a really fun course for those who like math proofs. It does not require much background knowledge and does not involve programming, which could be a good thing if you are taking other programming-heavy course.
